column1: LOUISVILLE, KY. (WDRB) -- Some Indiana tornado victims no longer have to boil their water.
Those under the Rural Membership Water Company in Henryville no longer are under a boil water advisory.
The advisory was put in place after the tornadoes knocked out power and utilities to hundreds in the area.
Officials collected 18 samples and found no bacteria existed - so the water is now safe to drink.
Copyright 2012 WDRB News.  All Rights Reserved.

Boil Water Notice CANCELED: Etoile Water Supply customers in Jeans Subdivision

column3: }

column1: NACOGDOCHES CO., TX (KTRE) – A boil water notice has been canceled immediately for Etoile Water Supply customers who live in Jeans Subdivision.
The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) required the notice after a line break was discovered in the system on March 12.
Customers no longer need to boil their water prior to consumption.
If you have questions concerning this matter, you may contact Charlie Luse at (936)854-2215.

column1: { alignment : '', timeoutDuration : '', highlightActiveNodes : false, level1ArrowPadding : '15', levelBorderWidths : { level1 : { top : '0' , right : '0' , bottom : '0' , left : '0' } , level2 : { top : '1' , right : '1' , bottom : '1' , left : '1' } } }
City council holds emergency meeting on water issues

column3: }

column1: CAMERON (UPDATE) - As of Monday (March 12), Cameron water customers no longer need to boil their water prior to consumption.
The rescinding of this boil order is due to adequate disinfection residual in the water system.
Any questions concerning this matter can be addressed by contacting City Hall at 254-697-6646.

CAMERON - Cameron city council members held an emergency hearing, Friday, to address the city's growing water issues. For weeks, residents have been complaining about brown and yellow water coming from the tap.
""So yellow, they're afraid to bathe in it. It just makes them want to go take another bath,"" local business owner Beverly Angel said.
Severn Trent, the company that supplies water to Cameron, briefed the council for the first time Friday since the complaints.
""I'm not here to make excuses today. We're the operator record for this water facility. and we're here to take responsibility,"" Severn Trent representative Dave Jentry said.
Jentry spoke for 45 minutes about what the company is doing to fix the problem, and what they think caused the water to be discolored.

""It could come from a lot of different areas, it could come from iron or manganese in the raw water. It can come from sloughing of the scale from cast iron pipes, which is caused by a reverse in flow or higher demand than normal, or water breaks or valve closings and openings,"" Jentry said.
To combat the brown water issue, Severn Trent did what's called a burnout, where the company flushes the system with high levels of chlorine.
""The good news is we had a severely reduced and greatly reduced number of complaints from brown water in this last week, and we contribute that to the flushing program,"" Jentry said.
With the brown water problem possibly out of the picture, residents are now dealing with a city boil water order.
Tuesday's test results showed parts of the city having low levels of chlorine.
However, Severn Trent is working to correct the imbalance and expects things to return to normal soon.
""Once we noticed the problem it was brought to our attention, we've now had three straight days of residuals that are in compliance,""
Jentry said. ""I really see no reason that we can't continue with that.""
Cameron City Manager Ricky Tow said the city is sending water samples to the lab everyday, and the boil water could be lifted by Wednesday.

Water advisory lifted in Pine Grove
Should President Trump still build the wall?

column1:
PINE GROVE - A boil water advisory was lifted for affected areas of the borough Friday.

The advisory, which was lifted at 2:57 p.m., was instituted at 8 a.m. Wednesday for those living on South Tulpehocken Street between Maple and Wood streets and on West Wood Street because a fire hydrant on South Tulpenhocken Street was being replaced, Mayor Kimberly Brown-Zerbe said. Replacement of the hydrant was completed Wednesday.

A leaky seal was replaced about two weeks ago but did not fix the problem, she said.

Borough workers were monitoring the situation and the decision was made to fix the hydrant.

As a safety precaution, the borough has a spare fire hydrant for such an occasion, she said.

Declaring a boil water advisory is standard practice and is issued whenever work in done to a water line, Brown-Zerbe said, adding customers were not in any danger.
